awd_titl_txt: AccelNet-Design: Soil and land management for food & water security, adaptation and mitigation of climate change
awd_abstract_narration:
Management of agricultural land and soil (ALS) systems are often disconnected from societal goals of food security and environmental sustainability. The ALS network facilitates cooperation among scientific disciplines, policy makers, Federal and State Agencies, agricultural producers, private industry, NGO’s, society members and land managers to develop resilient, sustainable practices of ALS in the context of both socioeconomic and biophysical interactions. This network would improve ALS management by considering changes to ALS management in a holistic way that considers equity, access to data, and information synthesis. This approach empowers diverse producers and land managers/stewards to adopt outcome-based (e.g., improved soil health, water quality and carbon sequestration) management. This team promotes research at the nexus of soil, water, land, and climate systems to increase sustainability of the management of agricultural land and soil. 

The ALS network (ALSNet): 1) develops coordination and communication mechanisms, 2) establishes team science processes and culture across multiple professional disciplines and groups to convert knowledge into action, 3) identifies and prioritizes knowledge gaps and opportunities, and 4) trains the next generation of a diverse and global workforce to develop solutions for the complex challenges of ALS systems. The project employs a team science approach that engages diverse partners to enhance interdisciplinarity, conducts ideation workshops, collaborates around shared vision, and develops research questions and synthesis papers. ALSNet supports broader strategic collaboration among U.S. research networks, global networks, professional societies, and social networks to integrate data, knowledge, and information on theoretical and applied research.  It uses a global perspective to narrow the gaps of scaling complexities, to understand tradeoffs, and to empower stakeholders to address the grand challenges associated with ALS. The team integrates biophysical, social, economic, and behavioral sciences that enhances the knowledge to action plan. The project will cross institutional boundaries and engage diverse stakeholders including consumers and industry partners, in both developed and developing nations, in the scientific discovery and implementation processes to build a plan for putting knowledge into action. This project is funded by the Office of International Science and Engineering (OISE).

The Accelerating Research through International Network-to-Network Collaborations (AccelNet) program is designed to accelerate the process of scientific discovery and prepare the next generation of U.S. researchers for multiteam international collaborations. The AccelNet program supports strategic linkages among U.S. research networks and complementary networks abroad that will leverage research and educational resources to tackle grand scientific challenges that require significant coordinated international efforts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Soil for Society Network (SSN) was designed to promote the nexus of soil, water, land, and climate systems to enhance the value we place to soil and transform the management of agricultural land and soil into a system that supports food security, water security, carbon management and biodiversity. Using a Team Science approach, we brought together 110 individuals representing 65 organizations (researchers, policy makers, federal and state agencies, agricultural producers, private industry, NGOs, society members) from over 18 countries (Benin, Canada, El Salvador, Finland, Ghana, India, Indonesia, Japan, Myanmar, Netherlands, Nigeria, Peru, Senegal, South Africa, Sweden, United Kingdom, United States, other countries in west Africa) to actively participate in the co-design of SSN through a series of face-to-face and virtual workshops.

During the two-year design phase of the project, we: 1) developed coordination and communication mechanisms among the network partners, 2) established team science processes and culture across multiple professional disciplines and groups within the network, 3) identified and prioritized knowledge gaps and opportunities for soil as a cross cutting discipline impacting all aspects of sustainable development, and 4) developed and provided opportunities for training early career researchers/professionals.

Key outcomes for the design phase of the project include:

  • An established network of professionals from academia, policy, and civil society that shares the vision to promote soils and their role in society.
  • A graphic-designed logo and website for the network (https://soilforsociety.org).
  • Trained and professionally developed a program manager.
  • Collated and synthesized literature and activities of all potential networks dealing with soils and its applications.
  • Developed and trained the core team in the concept and practice of using Team Science for convergence research.
  • Created a Team Science Manual to document the coordination and governance mechanisms for a Team Science Approach to the Soil for Society Network.
  • Identified common challenges, priorities, and overarching themes from a partner survey.
  • Implemented a series of virtual working group participatory workshops with emerging themes summarized and made open to all on the network website.
  • Conducted in-person workshops at the 2023 Water for Food Global Conference at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln and the 2023 IWRA World Water Congress in Beijing to reach the water science policy community.
  • Established a student, early-career researcher, and non-traditional practitioner team. The team designed and hosted a webinar series. Eight webinars were held and all were recorded and are available on the Soil for Society Network YouTube page.
  • Recruited and developed seven early career researchers from six institutions in the United States and United Kingdom who participated in organizing the webinar series, which required development of the following skillset: transdisciplinary communication and coordination, scheduling and project management, webinar facilitation, and concept development. Two early career researchers have since accepted faculty positions at R1 institutions in the United States (Oregon State University and North Dakota State University), and one early career researcher moved into a full-time position with a nonprofit organization (Center for Rural Affairs). 
  • Published four synthesis documents for the workshop series to the Soil for Society Network website.
  • Engaged the Core Team with numerous individuals representing organizations passionate about accelerating research through international network-to-network collaborations and specifically, research on land and soil conservation for food security and climate adaptation.
  • Grew membership to include 287 individuals who signed up to receive newsletters to keep in touch with our initiatives.
  • Formed new collaborations  among network members as an outcome of the icebreaking and team science network activities.
  • Disseminated information gathered and shared throughout the workshops and webinar series by the following mechanisms: website (publicly available), newsletter (to all subscribed members), LinkedIn (publicly available), and email (to all in attendance at the webinars and workshops).
  • Drafted an opinion piece authored by all members of the grant highlighting the principles and core values of the Soil for Society Network.
